step1.sentence: Hold your horses — let me finish explaining the plan before you start making changes.

step2.story: Jake was about to send the email to the entire company when his manager walked in. "Hold your horses," she said calmly, pointing at a typo in the subject line. He took a deep breath and fixed it just in time.

step3.story: Mia had been saving up for months and finally had enough money to buy a used car. She found one online that looked perfect and was ready to transfer the money immediately. Her dad noticed and said, "Hold your horses — have you even test-driven it yet?" Mia realized she had gotten so excited that she skipped all the important steps. The next day, she visited the seller and discovered the engine made a strange rattling noise. She was grateful her dad had slowed her down before she made a costly mistake.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 말(horse)을 붙잡아라, 즉 말을 멈추게 하라는 뜻입니다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 상대방이 너무 성급하게 행동하려 할 때 '잠깐, 서두르지 마'라는 의미로 사용합니다. 가벼운 충고나 제지의 느낌으로 일상 대화에서 자주 쓰입니다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 마차를 타던 시대에 말이 흥분하여 달려나가지 않도록 고삐를 잡으라는 뜻에서 유래했습니다. 19세기 미국 영어에서 널리 퍼졌습니다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 명령형이지만 공격적이지 않고, 친근하거나 유머러스한 톤으로 쓰입니다. 격식 있는 자리보다는 캐주얼한 대화에 어울립니다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: Hold your horses, we haven't even checked the weather forecast yet.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 서두르지 마, 우리 아직 일기예보도 확인 안 했잖아.
